scenes.label: *polonsave6
texts: Time to celebrate Takaoka's successful...or failed? ...Elopement! And welcome Aizaki and Hosho!

scenes.label: *storehis
texts: After our chat with Oz, we went to Symphony, where we were greeted by Wind.
He was convinced Momo and I were eloping, and wanted to throw us a welcome party for some reason, and, well...this was the situation now.
So, Aizaki, where are you from?
Whoa! Italy! Ciao ciao! Al denteee!
How about you make some authentic Italian pasta for our boy, huh?
Momo was a bit overwhelmed, but there was something about Wind's energy that compelled her to join in.
Nakano Symphonies was a sausage fest before, so it's gonna be nice having some girls around. We've got a real floral aura going on now.
Dude, why are you talking like you're part of the team?
He was just some weirdo who liked coming here. He enjoyed hanging out with us, but he never showed any intention of actually joining.
I like the retro feel this place has.
You do? I just wanna get the hell outta here.
The person who owned this place was one of my late dad's regular customers, back when he used to do his hacker work.
The jobs were never that big, though. My dad just had to locate people or objects, stuff like that.
After he died, Symphony's owner redirected those jobs to me instead.
I was left without a single relative, and had to feed myself somehow, so I had no choice but to take them on.
The owner ended up letting me use the place. Well, it's more like he gently forced me to use it.
I could appreciate someone who was worried for me...
...but I'd kinda been funneled into doing hacker work, so that level of consideration wasn't totally welcome.
Aizaki! Hosho! You can come here whenever you want! I'll welcome you anytime!
I see how it is... To you, I don't actually count as a girl.
Ah! Hold on! I'm a man who's happy as long as I can flirt with you, Yomi! I've no eyes for anyone but you!
You should've said that at the start, dummy...
Sure are! But that's just how lovers be, right? You'd know somethin' about that, wouldn't you, Aizaki?
Umm... May I ask who you're speaking with...?
Oh, you can't see Yomi! Sorry about that! I'll introduce you both later!
Momo was acting like nothing had happened...
...but the stuff she'd told us at the Chinese restaurant was straight-up unbelievable.

scenes.label: *kaisou
texts: I could see that Oz was dumbfounded, but my face was probably about as shocked.
The world will end on January 19th, 2038, at 3:14:07.
It wasn't so much Momo's statement about the world ending that surprised me...
...it was the fact that Momo was the one saying it.
It seemed way too insane to be real.
I'd convinced her to talk, but I was hearing it all for the first time, just like Oz.
I came to Japan to look for a hacker known as Kent Korihisa.
"Quests" was a term used for certain events.
There was this one godlike hacker causing trouble all over the world. They could do stuff that seemed like wizardry.
Their name had been well-known since their first appearance in the early 2010s.
But someone calling themselves "Cicada 3301" had appeared just last year.
It wasn't clear whether it was the same person.
But the newer one seemed to be sending challenges to hackers all around the world.
They went on 4chan's hacker board and posted crazy difficult puzzles involving the real world.
And those puzzles hinted at tragic events that actually happened soon after.
Cicada 3301 was the person causing the incidents. All the evidence was situational, but it seemed almost certain that that was the case.
It seemed like Cicada 3301 was challenging people.
Their actions were almost inviting people to "solve the puzzles and use the hints to prevent the incidents."
The hackers of the world were up to the challenge, of course.
The hackers on 4chan went and named Cicada 3301's posts, "quests."
And every time a new quest appeared, all the hackers rushed to complete them, eager to stop any incidents from taking place.
There had been four quests so far. Hackers from all over the world had taken them on, but not a single quest was completed.
The first incident was pretty tame, but the second one resulted in actual deaths.
By now, Cicada 3301 was widely regarded as a criminal, who just wanted to show off their brainpower.
Was that really the person Momo was looking for?
Even back in 2010, Kent Korihisa was considered a genius hacker.
That was the year he bypassed the Vatican's security systems and broke into its computer network.
The Vatican? I didn't expect to hear that.
He was quickly exposed and caught.
However, the pope and the other high-ranking people there chose not to punish him. Instead, they hired him as their head computer engineer.
After that, he was entrusted with the development of the Vatican's QCDC, Necro Pilgrimage, as well as their Earth Simulator.
That was...basically the same story as Asuma Soga's.
In 2012 though, shortly before Necro Pilgrimage's completion, Kent Korihisa suddenly vanished.
It's believed that the reason he disappeared was because he accidentally stumbled across a huge secret hidden in the Vatican's main computer.
The Secrets of FÃ¡tima are used and abused in occult conspiracy circles.
I've heard lots of versions of them. Including fictional ones.
Was this guy into the occult?
So, what's your take on the Third Secret of FÃ¡tima?
That the world will end 3 hours, 14 minutes, and 7 seconds into January 19th, 2038.

scenes.label: *chk
texts: I'd heard of them, but I didn't know much about them.
If things continue as they are, nobody will survive.
I want to save the world.
It's possible that Kent KorihisaâCicada 3301âknows how to do that.
He might be the world's savior.
That's why I must find him, no matter what.
Got any idea where he could be?
He was last seen here in Japan.
So that was why Momo came here, huh?
I really didn't believe he was anything like that.
Sure, his ability as a hacker was, like, monstrous.
But if you asked me, he was just some shithead who liked showing off.
I did think most hackers were unlikeable, but this guy was on another level.
Oz suddenly trailed off, muttering something about how that was when the Pope had suddenly resigned, and the <tips,30,Papal Conclave> had to be held.
Does that have something to do with the disappearance of this "Korihisa" guy, too?
Figured. The Third Secret of FÃ¡tima getting leaked has gotta be a big deal for the Vatican.
And that's the reason they're chasin' you?
Where does the army come in, then? They got nothin' to do with the Vatican.
The army took...I mean, was planning to take Momo to Haneda Airport, and hand her over to the Vatican's people.
I could've told him we'd both saw it with our own eyes, but explaining it would be a pain in the ass.
I did some independent investigation. Just leave it at that.
Interestin' stuff, but not what I was lookin' for.
What is it about Gai that you're investigating, anyway?
This and that. State stuff. Don't ask me anythin' else.
But I haven't finished eating yet.
Ugh, but you told me not to leave anything.
Oz kindly paid for the four of us, then walked out.
We'd just been told some absurd shit, but it looked like he'd taken it all in his stride.
As I was wondering why, Oz beckoned me over from outside the restaurant.
There's somethin' I wanted to ask ya.
Yesterday, you spoke like you knew I was gonna be there. How long were ya watchin' me?
I wasn't. I...I got an app that lets me save and load the world.
...That got anythin' to do with FÃ¡tima's secrets?
Oz sighed, and handed me a piece of paper.
Whoa! Never seen a paper one before.

scenes.label: *kaisou_end
texts: Come over if ya feel like talkin' again. And extend my invitation to the li'l lady.
Not even I could tell how much of what Momo had said was true.
If it was all an act though, she was one hell of an actress.
Either way, if she wanted to find someone, I'd just help her.
What kind of game is this?
Momo was staring into the screen of a tiny device as she pressed its buttons. She seemed real captivated.
If you like that egg so much, you can have it.
Hey, Polly, do you want one too? Do you?
I'm good. You can play Game of Life on your BMI, anyway.
You can! Do you know how? Wanna hear my lecture? Lecture, lecture, architecture!
But we can do it now.
